I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Regional cooperation and integration (RCI) is one of the seven strategic operational 
priorities under Strategy 2030.1 The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) aims to 
promote innovations in implementing Strategy 2030 Operational Plan for Priority 7 (RCI-OP) by 
(i) supporting sector and/or subsector diversification in RCI, (ii) fostering systematic development 
of  nonsovereign  RCI,  (iii)  exploring  opportunities  in  intersubregional  cooperation,  and  (iv) 
supporting developing member countries (DMCs) that have lagged in RCI.2 To the extent possible, 
the TA will integrate considerations and measures to address the risks posed by the coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19) pandemic and help Asian Development Bank (ADB) DMCs in post-pandemic 
recovery.  
 
2.  The TA is included in the 2020 Management-approved results-based work plan of ADB's 
Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Regional macroeconomic context. Asia and the Pacific has made steady progress in 
trade and investment and has thereby become a powerhouse of world growth. Asia’s share of 
intraregional trade by value reached 57% in 2019, comparable to the level in the European 
Union.4 However, there are emerging risks that the region must address. Because of lower 
demand from major industrialized economies, the trade tensions between the People’s Republic 
of China and the United States, the rising protectionism in the world, and, more recently, the 
impact of the COVID-19 pandemic lockdowns, developing Asia’s gross domestic product (GDP), 
which grew at 5.9% in 2018 and 5.1% in 2019, is expected to contract by 0.7% in 2020, the first 
contraction since the early 1960s.5 Affected by declining business confidence, Asia’s6 trade has 
also been adversely affected. Against this background, enhancing regional cooperation is more 
important than ever for Asia and the Pacific to navigate through this difficult time and restore its 
growth momentum. 
 
4.   ADB’s regional cooperation and integration operations. Under the previous RCI 
operational plan,7 ADB overall made steady progress toward achieving the RCI-related target set 
out in Strategy 2020.8 During 2017−2019, ADB approved 108 RCI projects totaling $15.8 billion, 
accounting for 25% in terms of project numbers and 24% by volume of ADB’s total operations. 
However, a deeper analysis revealed several key issues that were persistent in the structure of 
and approach to ADB’s RCI operations. Firstly, ADB’s RCI portfolio had focused heavily on 
transport connectivity (about 60%), which was dominated by road projects. While the focus on 
transport (and road) connectivity has reflected DMCs’ demands based on their development stage, 
ADB  needs  to  expand  trade  and  investment  interventions,  building  on  improved  transport 
connectivity. Within transport, not enough attention had been given to maritime transport (e.g., 
green ports development), the mode of ports, and the need for greater collaboration with the

private sector, despite the importance of maritime goods trade. Secondly, some DMCs (especially 
the small island developing states [SIDSs]), some areas (such as border areas) within DMCs, and 
some segments of the economy and society in the DMCs (such as small and medium-sized 
enterprises [SMEs], women, and poor households) have lagged in terms of access to connectivity 
and trade and investment opportunities. Thirdly, though the share of RCI operations for regional 
public goods (RPGs) saw some increase, it was still low relative to the magnitude of the risks 
faced by DMCs, especially as environmental and health risks spread across subregions. Fourthly, 
as SMEs accelerate their internationalization (driven both by technological opportunities and the 
need to look for new regional demand) and the direction of value chains change, strengthening 
intersubregional cooperation based on innovative analytical work will be crucial. Finally, given the 
broad scope and complexity of RCI operations, it is imperative that multisector and cross-thematic 
approaches be adopted. All of these require innovation in the RCI portfolio. 
 
5.  The  new  RCI-OP  therefore  calls  for  special  efforts  in  innovating  RCI  operations. 
Application of innovations defined by the RCI-OP will require prioritized actions to (i) diversify 
sectors or subsectors (e.g., by moving from road into other modes such as ports in the transport 
sector, with due attention to environmental sustainability), (ii) explore RCI opportunities for 
nonsovereign  investment  (e.g.,  by  promoting  private  sector  investments  in  environmentally 
sustainable transport, and generating opportunities for socially inclusive business, such as SMEs 
and services value chains, from cross-border trade or infrastructure connectivity to create wider 
economic benefits in economic corridors), and (iii) increase intersubregional cooperation and 
multisector  and  cross-thematic  approaches  (e.g.,  by  further  strengthening  RPG-related 
operations  to  address  the  increased  risks  caused  by  climate  change  and  transboundary 
communicable diseases, which have impact beyond individual subregions). 
 
6.  Impacts of the pandemic on regional cooperation and integration operations. The 
ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has accentuated the above-noted need to innovate RCI operations. 
It has created a regional (and global) health crisis which needs immediate responses from 
countries, both individually and collectively. It is also having profound and dire social and 
economic consequences at the regional level that may remain for some time. The pandemic has 
caused  serious shocks  through  various  channels:  it  has  disconnected  countries  by  cutting 
transport  links,  damaged  logistics  networks  that  serve  regional  production  and  trade,  and 
disrupted regional services value chains (particularly tourism and business travel) by halting the 
movement of people because of border closures and travel bans. The impact will likely fall more 
heavily on poorer countries with weaker institutional capacities and on the business segments, 
people, and geographic areas that are already vulnerable—especially SMEs, women, and the 
poor households involved in services trade—and communities in remote areas. 
 
7.  Therefore, over the medium term, the COVID-19 pandemic will necessitate changes (even 
a paradigm shift) in how RCI is approached under each pillar of the RCI-OP. Future RCI 
operations must incorporate health resilience to the extent possible through a multisector and  
cross-thematic approach. In transport, given the crucial role of maritime connectivity for goods 
trade, diversification into maritime connectivity should also consider aspects of cross-border 
communicable disease control. In trade and investment, the development of regional value chains 
(including service value chains) likewise needs to factor in health risks and adopt the latest 
technologies to facilitate safer movement of goods and people across borders, and SMEs 
(particularly those engaged in the internationalization process) need special support to recover 
from the shocks, including through enhanced regional financial cooperation. In RPGs, supporting 
the SIDSs, which are among the most vulnerable and challenged DMCs, should be prioritized, 
especially given the prevalence of concurrent compound risks of climate change threat and 
pandemics such as COVID-19.

3 
 
8.  It is in this context that the TA is designed. The TA will support implementation of the RCI-
OP by addressing selectively some of the most pressing needs of DMCs for medium-term post-
COVID-19 recovery in the areas of (i) developing higher-quality connectivity, focusing on greening 
and improving the resilience of maritime transport; (ii) expanding regional and global trade and 
investment, focusing on developing resilient regional service value chains and supporting SMEs 
through regional financial cooperation; and (iii) supporting SIDSs in mitigating climate change and 
transboundary health risks. While the TA is not intended to be an immediate response to the 
COVID-19 crisis, due consideration has been given to the need for integrating health resilience in 
RCI operations over the medium term by mitigating accentuated risks to maritime goods trade 
growth recovery, promoting wider socially inclusive benefits from trade and investment, and 
reducing post-pandemic impacts on environmental sustainability.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA will be aligned with the following impact: inclusive, sustainable, and resilient intra- 
and intersubregional cooperation and integration in Asia and the Pacific supported (footnote 2). 
The TA will have the following outcome: innovative RCI operations in the areas of connectivity, 
trade and investment, and RPGs increased in selected DMCs.9  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Best practices and investment opportunities for green and resilient port 
development identified. This output aims to support diversification of the transport subsector 
under the RCI-OP’s connectivity pillar. Ports are essential for the global economy, as most trade 
happens by sea. The People’s Republic of China and Southeast Asia have seen the fastest 
growth in maritime traffic since 2010. However, economic recovery and future growth will require 
shipping and port operations that are clean and minimize water and air pollution, ecosystem 
degradation, greenhouse gas emissions, and the threats from transboundary communicable 
diseases as evidenced by the current COVID-19 pandemic. This output will strengthen the 
existing efforts of the selected countries in Asia and the Pacific (involving all ADB’s subregional 
programs) in greening and enhancing the resilience of ports by reducing the environmental impact 
and increasing the emergency response preparedness of ports for major health and other disaster 
risks.  The  output  will  also  strengthen  ADB’s  collaboration  with  the  private  sector  in  port 
development. Development of green and resilient ports and other maritime transport infrastructure 
will also help ensure the security of transport connectivity in case of any health-related crisis, and 
reduce risks from operations on surrounding cities and communities.  
 
11.  A study will be conducted to (i) guide voluntary efforts by the selected regional ports in 
adopting standards and practices that are aligned with international norms; (ii) explore the 
feasibility of and develop a business plan for setting up a facility to help port authorities and port 
operators improve infrastructure and practices for complying with improved standards; and (iii) 
identify opportunities for ADB to work with port authority associations, private terminal operator 
associations, and other parties in facilitating peer-to-peer dialogue and knowledge sharing on 
sound environmental, disaster, and health management practices and emergency preparedness; 
coordinating  sovereign  policy  actions;  and  catalyzing  green  and  resilient  port  investments 
(including nonsovereign investments) in Asia and the Pacific.   
 
9 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
 
12.  Output 2: Knowledge on regional tourism value chains for recovery and resilience 
improved. This output supports regional tourism and travel services value chain development 
under the RCI-OP’s trade and investment pillar. Tourism receipts and business travel are very 
important for developing Asia, accounting for more than 10% of GDP in almost half of ADB’s 
members and more than 40% for some economies like Maldives and Palau. Tourism has been 
one of the industries worst affected by COVID-19, with international tourism arrivals into Asia and 
the Pacific dropping by 98% in April.10 Recovery of the tourism industry is expected to be slow. 
This presents a challenge for Asia and the Pacific to reduce the immediate negative economic 
and social impacts, but also presents an opportunity to orientate recovery efforts to support long-
term sustainable development goals. It is therefore important for ADB, in the medium term, to 
strengthen its support for the development of regional tourism value chains which contribute to 
resilient, inclusive, and sustainable growth.  
  
13.  This output will seek to identify initiatives that ADB can undertake with selected DMCs 
(including stakeholders from the public sector, private sector, and civil society) through its 
subregional programs to strengthen the resilience of the regional tourism (and business travel) 
value  chains  against  transboundary  health  risks  and  support  post-COVID-19  recovery. 
Specifically, this output will (i) increase knowledge on the contribution of tourism to resilient, 
inclusive, and sustainable trade and economic development within Asia and the Pacific; (ii) 
identify  and  understand  key  intervention  areas  and  policy  recommendations  for  regional 
cooperation on tourism; (iii) conduct a scoping study for trialing an innovative solution in one key 
identified intervention area; and (iv) understand and identify ADB’s comparative advantage in 
providing financing for regional cooperation on tourism after COVID-19 and leveraging multiple 
enabling  sectors,  such  as  urban  infrastructure  and  biodiversity,  as  well  as  private  sector 
investments. Emphasis will be on medium-term recommendations for the recovery of the tourism 
industry (e.g., through opportunities offered by domestic tourism and travel bubbles) and its long-
term sustainability. Special attention will be paid to identifying measures that could mitigate health 
risk impacts on the participation of vulnerable groups (e.g., enterprises led by women, and border 
communities) in the tourism value chains. 
 
14.  Output 3: Opportunities to cooperate for resilient and sustainable livelihoods in 
atoll nations explored. This output responds to the priority that the RCI-OP places on supporting 
RPG-related operations, especially in the most vulnerable countries like SIDSs. The four low-lying 
nations of Kiribati, Maldives, Marshall Islands, and Tuvalu are facing the dual threats of climate 
change (particularly sea-level rise) and health risks like COVID-19, which are often exacerbated 
by the weak institutional capacity in these atoll nations. The rapid spread of COVID-19 and the 
breakdown of global supply chains aggravated their preexisting vulnerability, particularly given 
their dependence on imported food and medical supplies. In recent years, the leaders of atoll 
nations have started to establish platforms and fora to discuss and jointly address their shared 
risks and challenges.11 
 
15.  A study will be conducted to identify key opportunities for collaboration among the atolls 
in the Pacific and South Asia in designing integrated solutions to tackle their vulnerabilities. In line 
with the priorities outlined by atoll nations, the study will identify opportunities and recommend 
actions for developing blue economies (such as sustainable tourism and fisheries) through

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,500,000,13 of which (i) $2,000,000 for outputs 1 and 2 will 
be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  United  Kingdom  Fund  for  Asia  Regional  Trade  and 
Connectivity (ARTCF) under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership 
Facility and administered by ADB; and (ii) $500,000 for output 3 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund.14 The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2.  
 
17.  For the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund, eligible expenditures for financing 
include (i) operational expenses of the TA in the form of consulting services, (ii) training and 
capacity development for eligible DMCs, and (iii) minimal equipment and other goods which 
though eligible are not expected to be incurred under this project. Civil works and procurement of 
large-scale equipment (such as machinery and other capital equipment) and salary for permanent 
staff of TA executing and/or implementing agencies are typical noneligible expenditures. The 
ARTCF will undertake TA activities in eligible countries as specified under the fund guidelines 
and/or as agreed with the Department for International Development of the United Kingdom 
(DFID). It will finance TA operational expenses in the form of consulting services; training events, 
conferences, and workshops; and related activities. It will not be used for civil works, procurement 
of large-scale equipment, and permanent staffing costs.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  ADB, through the Regional Cooperation and Integration Thematic Group, will administer 
the TA during December 2020−November 2023. A One ADB approach will be applied in TA 
implementation as well as monitoring and evaluation of the outputs, with close collaboration with 
regional departments (including resident missions in the participating DMCs), the Economic 
Research and Regional Cooperation Department, the Private Sector Operations Department, and 
relevant sector and thematic groups. The TA will build on existing work in regional departments 
under  ADB’s  subregional  programs  and  focus  on  filling  the  gaps  and  strengthening  the 
intersubregional links in the areas covered. Selection of DMCs to participate in the TA will be done 
in consultation with regional departments. Government concurrence for country-level activities will 
be secured before TA activities are implemented. Findings and recommendations and knowledge 
generated under the TA will be widely disseminated through multicountry forums, knowledge 
sharing events, web-based channels, and policy dialogues organized under ADB’s subregional

19.  Consulting services. The TA will require 102 person-months of international and national 
consulting services from a firm and individuals in the various areas covered by the project. 
Resource persons will be engaged, as needed, to provide qualitative and quantitative inputs 
supporting and supplementing the studies required by the TA, including participation in seminars, 
meetings, training events, and dissemination workshops. Output-based or lump-sum contracts, 
indefinite contracts or framework agreements for consulting services, and use of fixed out-of-
pocket expenses will be considered where appropriate with the concurrence of the Procurement, 
Portfolio and Financial Management Department. ADB will engage the consultants following the 
ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project 
administration instructions and/or staff instructions.15 
 
20.  Cofinancier requirements. During TA implementation, semiannual progress reports, 
including an overview of expenditures, will be provided through the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration Thematic Group to the ARTCF. Any major changes in the TA scope and objectives 
will be discussed with the DFID. The TA completion report will also be shared with the DFID.
